__Top-Down-Policies, z.B. Empfehlungen GEBF & AEPF__    
  
_"Forschende stellen Materialien zur Vorgehensweise der Datenauswertung **reproduzierbar** (sofern möglich) und leicht zugänglich bereit, um die Nachvollziehbarkeit, Replizierbarkeit und Weiterverwendung von Ergebnissen zu erleichtern."_
  
\

__European Research Council__  
*Grantees should describe the protocols used to structure their data and indicate the metadata standards applied. This will allow other scientists to make an assessment, to attempt to __reproduce the conclusions derived from the dataset__ [...] and potentially reuse the data for further research.* [@erc.2022, S. 5]
:::
::::


## Theorie


:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}

\

* ~3,2 % der Forschenden teilen ihren code [@krahmer.2023]<br /><br /><br />
* Interindividuelle Unterschiede:
  - Einerseits: Anstieg der wahrgenommenen Bedeutsamkeit und Vorteile, sowie Zunahme von Open Science Praktiken [@borycz.2023;@ferguson.2023; @cao.2023, @unesco.2023]
  - Andererseits: Open Science policy alienation [@lilja.2021]<br /><br /><br />



:::
::::

:::{.notes}

* Bedeutet für einige Forschende eine Veränderung ihrerer bisherigen Praxis
* CAMCC
  - Ob und wie Forschende mit Open Science-Botschaften engagen, hängt von der Bewertung der Botschaft ab
  - betrachtet neben einer kognitiven auch eine affektive Komponente
  
:::

## Methode
#### Stichprobe

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="49%"}

**_N_ = 155 Forschende** _(a priori Power-Analyse: 90% Power)_

* mit einer quantitativ-empirischen Publikation 
* in der Bildungsforschung 
* in 2024 
* als Corresponding Author

:::
::: {.column width="49%"}

**Alter:** _M_ = 43.01 Jahre (_SD_ = 10,69)  
**40 Länder** vertreten; häufigste: 

* Deutschland (*n* = 19)
* USA (*n* = 16)
* Türkei (*n* = 11)

:::
::::

```{r}
#| eval: true

data <- rio::import(here("data/main_study_data.csv")) %>%
  dplyr::filter(!is.na(submitdate)) %>%
  rename_with(~ gsub("\\[(\\w+)\\]$", "_\\1", .x))

data_geschl <- data %>%
  group_by(gender) %>%
  dplyr::summarize(count = length(gender)) %>%
  dplyr::mutate(lab.ypos = c(116, 41, 1),
                gender = factor(gender,
                                levels = c("f", "m", "nb"),
                                labels = c("weiblich", "männlich", "non-binär")))

p1 <- ggplot(data_geschl, aes(x = 2, y = count, fill = gender)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", color = "white") +
  coord_polar(theta = "y", start = 0) +
  geom_text(aes(y = lab.ypos, x = 1.3, label = count), 
            color = "black", size = 6) +
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "C",
                       guide = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE),
                       name = NULL) +
  theme_void() +
  xlim(0.5, 2.5) +
  theme(plot.margin =  margin(0,0,0,0),
        text = element_text(size = 20),
        )

data_career <- data %>%
  dplyr::mutate(careerStage_coded = case_when(
                                      careerStage == 1 ~ "Doktorand:in",
                                      careerStage == 2 ~ "Post-Doc",
                                      careerStage > 2 & careerStage < 6 ~ "Professor:in",
                                      careerStage > 5 ~ "Andere"
  )) %>%
  group_by(careerStage_coded) %>%
  dplyr::summarize(count = length(careerStage_coded)) %>%
  dplyr::mutate(lab.ypos = c(150, 14, 40, 90),
                careerStage_coded = factor(careerStage_coded,
                                levels = c("Andere", "Professor:in", "Post-Doc", "Doktorand:in")))

p2 <- ggplot(data_career, aes(x = 2, y = count, fill = careerStage_coded)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", color = "white") +
  coord_polar(theta = "y", start = 0)+
  geom_text(aes(y = lab.ypos, x = 1.3, label = count), 
            color = "black", size = 6)+
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "C",
                       guide = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE),
                       name = NULL) +
  theme_void() +
  xlim(0.5, 2.5) +
  theme(plot.margin =  margin(0,0,0,0),
        text = element_text(size = 20),
        )
```

## Methode
\
\

__Consider the following scenario__

:::{.box-grey}
Imagine you are applying for a grant from a research funder to conduct a study on the relationship between students’ self-regulated learning strategies and their academic performance. You plan to administer a survey with quantitative measures to a sample of university students, collecting data on their use of specific learning strategies, related academic outcomes, and demographic characteristics.  
  
The funder's information for grantees states that the data analyses should be *computationally reproducible*.   
*"Grantees should allow other scientists to make an assessment, to attempt to reproduce the conclusions derived from the dataset, and potentially reuse the data for further research."*  
  
This means that you should document and provide the data as well as data analysis in such a way that other researchers can understand and follow the steps to obtain exactly the same results as you. Ideally, the other researcher will not have any additional costs (such as having to buy software) that exceed the internet costs of downloading your research materials.
:::

## Methode
\
\

#### Statistische Analysen

* Multivariate Bayesian Regression (brms)
* Drei Outcomes (Challenge Appraisal, Threat Appraisal, Engagement) simultan modelliert
* Test gerichteter Hypothesen (siehe Präregistrierung)

## Diskussion
\

* Interpretation von *reform messages* hängt mit Ressourcen zusammen (auch wenn Varianzaufklärung größer sein könnte)
* Passend zum CAMCC: Erfolgserwartung, Opportunitätskosten und Unterstützung durch Infrastruktur als Prädiktoren
* positive Gefühle (challenge) sagen günstige Verarbeitung vorher
* negative Gefühle (threat) sagen Oberflächenverarbeitung vorher

\
\

#### Limitations

* Unklar warum Unterstützung durch Infrastruktur zu Bedrohungswahrnehmung führen sollte
* Unklar warum Opportunitätskosten zu Herausforderung führen sollte
* Operationalisierung von Erfahrung misst kaum interindividuelle Unterschiede

## Methode
### Stichprobe

* **Rekrutierung:** Corresponding Authors quantitativ-empirischer Publikationen (2024) im Bereich Education aus Web of Science
  - Ausgangsdatensatz: *N* = 48,484 Publikationen
  - Nach Filterung: *N* = 10,960 quantitativ-empirische Studien
  - Zufallsstichprobe in drei Batches (je 1550, 3100, 3100)
* **Finale Stichprobe:** *N* = 155 Forschende (a priori Power-Analyse: 90% Power)
* **Geschlecht:** 73 weiblich, 81 männlich, 1 nicht-binär
* **Alter:** *M* = 43.01 Jahre (*SD* = 10.69)
* **Karrierestufe:** 
  - Doktorand*innen: _n_ = 28 (18.1%)
  - Postdocs: *n* = 21 (13.5%)
  - Professur (Junior/Mid/Senior): *n* = 95 (61.3%)
  - Andere (Research staff/Non-faculty): *n* = 11 (7.1%)
* **Länder:** 40 Länder vertreten; häufigste: Deutschland (*n* = 19), USA (*n* = 16), Türkei (*n* = 11)
* **Incentivierung:** Spende von 8,50€ pro Teilnahme an eine von vier Charities


## Methode
```{r}
#| eval: true

# Länderdaten
countries <- data$country

# Häufigkeiten zählen (leere Strings entfernen)
country_counts <- data.frame(iso2c = countries) %>%
  filter(iso2c != "") %>%
  count(iso2c) %>%
  mutate(country_name = countrycode(iso2c, "iso2c", "country.name"),
         country_name = case_when(country_name == "United Kingdom" ~ "UK",
                                  country_name == "United States" ~ "USA",
                                  TRUE ~ country_name))

# Weltkarte laden
world_map <- map_data("world")

# Ländernamen in den Map-Daten anpassen
world_map <- world_map %>%
  left_join(country_counts, by = c("region" = "country_name"))


# Alternative: Diskrete Farbskala für bessere Lesbarkeit
ggplot(world_map, aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill = n)) +
  geom_polygon(color = "white", size = 0.1) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma", 
                       na.value = "grey90",
                       name = "Anzahl\nTeilnehmende",
                       breaks = c(1, 5, 10, 15, 20),
                       direction = -1) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    panel.grid = element_blank(),
    axis.text = element_blank(),
    axis.title = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks = element_blank()
  ) +
  coord_fixed(1.3)
```

## Theorie

* Forschung entwickelt sich konstant weiter, Forschende müssen immer wieder mit 



* Reform messages by DFG, ... + genutzter Ausschnitt zeigen
* Stellt bisherige Praktiken infrage (~3,2 % der Forschenden teilen ihren code, Krähmer et al. 2023)
* Es zeigt sich allerdings, dass es ein geringes Engagement 


* eine der zentralen Quellen für eine fehlende Umsetzung werden fehlende Ressourcen angegeben

-> Einführunge Gregoire
* Diese determinieren, inwiefern die reform message als eine herausforderung oder threat wahrgenommen wird
* und sich deshalb mit den Inhalten auseinandersezten
-> reform fatique vs. erfolgreiche umsetzung

## Study

### Vignette (option 1)

::: {.highlight-grey .bigger}

Think of a current research project in which you are collecting and analyzing quantitative data. Now imagine that the research team assigns you the task of ensuring that your data and results are *computationally reproducible*.

This means that you have to provide the data and analysis code in such a way that another researcher can use it and produce exactly the same results as you. Ideally, the other researcher will not have any additional costs (such as having to buy software) that exceed the internet costs of downloading your research materials. Ideally, you should also take into account that your analyses run on different system requirements (e.g., Windows, Mac) and software versions (e.g., older versions).

:::

## Study


### Vignette (option 2) 
adopted from ERC (2022) ["Open Research Data and Data Management Plans. Information for ERC grantees" (V4.1)](https://erc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/document/file/ERC_info_document-Open_Research_Data_and_Data_Management_Plans.pdf)  
\

::: {.highlight-grey}
Imagine you are planning to submit a study to a research funder on the relationship between students' self-directed learning strategies and their academic performance. A survey with quantitative measures will be administered to a sample of university students, collecting data on their use of specific learning strategies, corresponding academic outcomes and demographic variables.  
  
The information for grantees from the research funder states that the data analyses should be *computationally reproducible*.  
"Grantees should allow other scientists to make an assessment, to attempt to reproduce the conclusions derived from the dataset, and potentially reuse the data for further research."  
  
This means that you should provide the data and analysis code in such a way that other researchers can use it and produce exactly the same results as you. [Ideally, the other researcher will not have any additional costs (such as having to buy software) that exceed the internet costs of downloading your research materials.] [Ideally, you should also take into account that your analyses run on different system requirements (e.g., Windows, Mac) and software versions (e.g., older versions)].
:::

```{r}
data <- data %>%
  mutate(resourcePerson_eos4_R = 7 - resourcePerson_eos4,
         engage_cognitive01_R = 7 - engage_cognitive01,
         engage_cognitive04_R = 7 - engage_cognitive04,
         engage_cognitive06_R = 7 - engage_cognitive06,
         engage_cognitive08_R = 7 - engage_cognitive08,
         engage_cognitive09_R = 7 - engage_cognitive09
         ) %>%
  dplyr::select(-c(resourcePerson_eos4,
                   engage_cognitive01,
                   engage_cognitive04,
                   engage_cognitive06,
                   engage_cognitive08,
                   engage_cognitive09)) %>%
  mutate(resource_perso_eos = rowMeans(across(contains("resourcePerson_eos")), 
                                         na.rm = TRUE),
         resource_perso_lva = rowMeans(across(contains("resourcePerson_va")), 
                                         na.rm = TRUE),
         resource_perso_exp = experience,
         resource_infra = rowMeans(across(contains("resourceInfra_")), 
                                    na.rm = TRUE),
         appraisal_challe = rowMeans(across(contains("challenge_")), 
                                      na.rm = TRUE),
         appraisal_threat = rowMeans(across(contains("threat_")), 
                                       na.rm = TRUE),
         engagement = rowMeans(across(contains("engage_cognitive")), 
                               na.rm = TRUE))
```

## Hypothesis 1
Researchers differ in whether they perceive the demand for transparency in data analysis as a threat or a challenge.  
  
__Challenge__
```{r}
fit_var_challe <- brm(appraisal_challe ~ 1, # Intercept-only model -> residual 
                                            # variance = total variance
                      data = data)

post <- as_draws_df(fit_var_challe) # draw posteriors

quantile(post$sigma^2, # Residual-SD squared = variance
         probs = c(0.025, 0.5, 0.975)) # Median and CI of variance
rm(post)
```

__Threat__
```{r}
fit_var_threat <- brm(appraisal_threat ~ 1, # Intercept-only model -> residual 
                                            # variance = total variance
                      data = data)

post <- as_draws_df(fit_var_threat) # draw posteriors

quantile(post$sigma^2, # Residual-SD squared = variance
         probs = c(0.025, 0.5, 0.975)) # Median and CI of variance
rm(post)
```


```{r}
data_std <- data %>%
  mutate(resource_perso_eos = scale(resource_perso_eos),
         resource_perso_lva = scale(resource_perso_lva),
         resource_perso_exp = scale(resource_perso_exp),
         resource_infra = scale(resource_infra),
         appraisal_challe = scale(appraisal_challe),
         appraisal_threat = scale(appraisal_threat),
         engagement = scale(engagement))

model_appaisal <- brms::bf(appraisal_challe ~ resource_perso_eos + 
                             resource_perso_lva + 
                             resource_perso_exp + 
                             resource_infra)

model_threat <- brms::bf(appraisal_threat ~ resource_perso_eos + 
                           resource_perso_lva + 
                           resource_perso_exp + 
                           resource_infra)

model_engagement <- brms::bf(engagement ~ appraisal_challe + 
                               appraisal_threat + 
                               resource_perso_eos + 
                               resource_perso_lva + 
                               resource_perso_exp + 
                               resource_infra)

fit_brms <- brms::brm(model_appaisal +
                        model_threat + 
                        model_engagement +
                        set_rescor(FALSE),
                      data = data_std,
                      cores = 4,
                      chains = 4,
                      iter = 4000)

summary(fit_brms)
brms::bayes_R2(fit_brms)
```

## Hypothesis 2a
Higher levels of personal resources (e.g., stronger expectancy of success, lower perceived loss of valued alternatives), infrastructural support, and prior experience are associated with lower threat appraisals regarding transparency in data analysis.  

__Expectancy of success__
```{r}
hypothesis(fit_brms, "appraisalthreat_resource_perso_eos < 0")
```

__Loss of valued alternatives__
```{r}
hypothesis(fit_brms, "appraisalthreat_resource_perso_lva > 0")
```

__Infrastructural support__
```{r}
hypothesis(fit_brms, "appraisalthreat_resource_infra < 0")
```

__Experience__
```{r}
hypothesis(fit_brms, "appraisalthreat_resource_perso_exp < 0")
```



## Hypothesis 3a
Stronger threat appraisals of transparency in data analysis are associated with lower cognitive and behavioral engagement with the topic.  
  
__Cognitive engagement__
```{r}
hypothesis(fit_brms, "engagement_appraisal_threat < 0")
```


__Behavioral engagement__

